Cards start slow before rolling past Lafayette

28-2 run late in first half turns 2-point hole into comfortable win

Cards start slow before rolling past Lafayette

The Courier-Journal 10:09 p.m. EST November 28, 2014

Louisvilles Bria Smith (21) steals the ball from Lafayette forward Harriet Ottewill-Soulsby (14) during the first half.(Photo: Jamie Rhodes/USA Today Sports)

CONNECT 3 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Another game, another blowout.

The University of Louisville women's basketball team shook off a slow start to systematically dismantle Lafayette 102-61 at the KFC Yum! Center on Friday night.

Seven players scored in double figures for U of L. Freshman Myisha Hines-Allen scored 14 of her 18 points in the first half. She connected on 8 of her first 9 shots and finished 9 of 13. Jude Schimmel had 15 points and Mariya Moore added 11 points and 10 assists.

No. 12 U of L (6-0) has won all of its games by double digits with the closest margin being 13 points. On Friday, it shot 52 percent, scored a season-best in points and had 26 assists to six turnovers. It outscored Lafayette 33-2 in points off turnovers.

Not sure if Thanksgiving was to blame, but the Cardinals were a step slow on defense early.

    "It comes with maturity," Schimmel said. "We were playing Lafayette, but as a team we're not preparing for games like this. We're preparing for later on in the season when we play bigger, better teams. We'll take it as a learning experience."

    Lafayette made 8 of its first 9 shots (4 of 4 from three-point range) to take a 20-18 lead. This must have felt great to Maddie Peabody. The Sacred Heart alum had seven of Lafayette's points in her return to her hometown. Peabody received an ovation from the crowd when the starting lineups were announced.

    It took a while, but U of L coach Jeff Walz finally saw his defense wake up. The Cardinals' pressure ignited a 28-2 run starting with 14 straight points. They led by as many as 30 points in the first half before settling for a 56-28 halftime lead.

    "What we tried to do after the first four or five minutes was to extend our press," Walz said. "We trapped earlier and tried to cause a little more chaos. Once we got them into a situation where they were chasing us instead of making us chase them, I thought it threw them off."

    After Lafayette's Jamie O'Hare's second straight three-pointer put the visitors ahead 20-18, the Leopards went 1 for 13 the rest of the half. They had 15 turnovers in the half that U of L converted into 23 points.

    U of L: Your predictions for U of L-UK football game

    AND: Ticket demand lower for late-season Gov. Cup

    Bria Smith, coming off a triple-double against Western Kentucky, made a pair of free throws to tie the score at 20. Then reserve Emmonnie Henderson made a pair of layups to put the Cardinals ahead to stay. Later, Schimmel, who sat out an early stretch after getting hit in the nose, re-entered and immediately made a trey to push the run to 10-0 and a 28-20 UofL lead.

    The Cardinals would score 14 straight points, capped by Hines-Allen's lay-up that made it 32-20. By the time the 28-2 run was over, U of L held a 42-26 lead culminated by another Hines-Allen basket. During the run, it forced Lafayette into eight turnovers in a 2:06 stretch.

    The technical knockout was delivered in the first half. After halftime, U of L continued to roll.

    Story continues after video.

    Cards roll 102-61

    Schimmel, who entered this game shooting 27.8 percent, was 5 of 7.

    "I couldn't really figure out what was wrong with my shot," she said. "For the last week, (it's been) short. I've been aiming longer for the back of the rim."

    Note: Walz said that Cortnee Walton (broken toe) is out of a walking boot. He said she could be back in two weeks.

    "She's been doing some running," he said. "'It's a slow progression right now."
